Background ACCs bring together key industry, employer, and community representatives to identify priorities and opportunities for employment and economic development as well as linked education and training issues in their region. A network of 58 committees Australia-wide was established to provide regional leadership so regions could make the most of their economic and labour market strengths. The ACC Network is allocated operating funds through the Regional Assistance Program. The Government considers the ACC Network an important element in the achievement of its goals for employment and economic growth in metropolitan, regional and rural Australia. It has a primary communication role within its local community to both promote and disseminate government programs and initiatives; and provide advice and feedback on the impact of those initiatives to better inform implementation of the employment services market reforms. ACCs will continue to be administered by and operate under the Department of Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business. Through that department ACCs will have a strong relationship with the Departments of Education, Training and Youth Affairs and Transport and Regional Services. The Department of Transport and Regional Services has a primary role in coordinating programs and activities that affect rural and on a regional Australia across a range of portfolios. A coordinating group will be established to enable practical implementation of the principles underlying the MOU. The group will be chaired by Department of Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business and comprise of representatives from the Departments of Transport and Regional Services and Education, Training and Youth Affairs. (2) What is the head of power in the Defence Force Discipline Act 1982 that allows for the development of new punishments. (3) Have the standing orders provided for new punishments. (4) What is the specific standing order covering attitude adjustment training. Mr Bruce Scott-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (1) The use of the Defence Force Corrective Establishment standing orders as a means of indicating new punishments was not referred to in the Department of Defence's submission to the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Inquiry into Military Justice Procedures in the Australian Defence Force. Punishments that follow from the formal disciplinary process are prescribed in the Defence Force Discipline Act 1982 and there is no other source or authority for the imposition of punishments. The Defence Force Corrective Establishment is a military establishment that has a role in the implementation of certain sentences awarded to Australian Defence Force members by Service Tribunals. The Defence Force Corrective Establishment standing orders are not a means of indicating new punishments and have no relevance to the formal disciplinary procedures of sentence established by the Defence Force Discipline Act 1982. As the Defence Force Corrective Establishment cannot in itself award sentences to Australian Defence Force members, its standing orders were not referred to in that context in the submission to the Inquiry. (2) Only Service Tribunals under the Defence Force Discipline Act 1982 may award disciplinary punishments as prescribed by the Act. There is no head of power that permits a Service Tribunal or a Defence entity, such as the Defence Force Corrective Establishment, to develop and impose new punishments. Development of new punishments requires legislative amendment. (3) The Defence Force Corrective Establishment standing orders do not provide for new punishments, nor were they intended to provide for punishments in terms of the Defence Force Discipline Act 1982. The standing order provision for 'Discipline Tours', which over time transformed into 'Attitude Adjustment Training', was solely intended to familiarise selected Australian Defence Force members with the procedures involved in serving detention at the Defence Force Corrective Establishment should they later be awarded detention by a Service Tribunal in accordance with the provisions of the Defence Force Discipline Act 1982. (4) The Defence Force Corrective Establishment standing orders of June 1996 at Annex B to Chapter 5 included a flow-chart relating to Discipline Tour procedures. In December 1996, the Defence Force Corrective Establishment was subsumed by the Military Police School. The Military Police School standing orders were amended to incorporate the operation of the Defence Force Corrective Establishment, and its standing orders included staff duty statements which detailed instructions for conducting Discinor pline Tours. Discipline Tours were suspended in July 1997 and all reference to Discipline Tours was deleted from subsequent standing orders. The practice of Discipline Tours or Attitude Adjustment training has not been undertaken since July 1997, is there any proposal to reintroduce the practice.
